ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course taught me so much! Yes, I learned a bit about archaeology, but I also learned so much about Egyptian history, the important pharaohs, architecture, Egyptian culture, religion, burial practices, agriculture, military organization, etc. This course in some ways functioned as a survey of Egyptian history seen through the lens of archaeology, by describing historical events and then using archaeology to back it up, which I thought was a perfect way to go about it. There was almost too much to cover, though, and I do feel bad that we did not quite make it all the way to the Ptolemaic period, though I am not personally disappointed as this is not my favorite era of Egyptian history.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Marouard is very kind and interesting, had well-prepared, well thoughout-out lectures. He also provided good readings on Canvas which I think improved my understanding of the class. The workload was not too heavy and seemed reasonable, and was also very accommodating for COVID issues.
Weaknesses: It was too bad that we fell behind the schedule, and I wish we had had more options for discussion and interaction with our peers. I did ask a few questions, but perhaps there could have been a few classes where we all read the same article(s) with different viewpoints on a topic and then came to discuss them. I know this is very difficult over Zoom, though.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures over Zoom were as good as any in my opinion, but as I said in the previous question there could have been more opportunities for interaction or collaboration/discussion with other members of the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Take this class! Professor Marouard is so interesting, and it is such a great survey of Egyptian history which to my knowledge has not existed in such a comprehensive form at Yale in the last few years, if ever. Even for non-humanities students, there are still lots of facts and descriptions to memorize, and you have to recall particular pieces of evidence which support each claim, so it is very intellectually stimulating regardless of your major. You also put into it what you get out of it; the weekly workload is very low, so you could just attend lecture and you will still learn a TON of material, but by doing the readings and even looking things up on your own time you will be better able to synthesize a lot of the broader themes, which for me was a fun thing and improved my understanding of the material.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
